posts.name: Ezra
posts.cooked: I was looking into components that could level up our electronics and I stumbled across Jhoinrch-Converter-Canable Adapter, and similar CANbus testers, and I was wondering if something like this was usable for FIRST Robotics Competitionâ€™s devices and if it could actually provide benefits. Has anyone used anything similar or has more knowledge that could be helpful? Are there any other devices or components that could help an intermediate electronics level team?

posts.cooked: You would probably be better off using a multimeter to check if the CAN Controller Area Network is shorted or if it fails to reach its intended destination. While this allows you to monitor CAN signals, this approach isn't particularly helpful since most FIRST Robotics Competition CAN problems stem from incorrect wiring rather than CAN signal issues. Moreover, most CAN activity can typically be observed through the competition's dashboard.

posts.name: Mr. Siefen | 453
posts.cooked:
If itâ€™s designed after the CAN abbreviation it would work with CAN 2.0 devices and allow you to use the Phoenix Framework API (motor control for CTR electronic devices older gen devices probably not Kraken falcon etc) on something like a Raspberry Pi or Nvidia Jetson.  

Testing the health of a CAN network involves using multimeters for continuity dashboards for bandwidth and various tools for changing your device IDs. Additional hardware wonâ€™t provide significant new insights here.  

Examining the signals under an oscilloscope and looking for noise in the signal and where it is coming from is something that might interest someone with more expertise in this area though details on how to do this arenâ€™t provided.

posts.name: Dan Nichols
posts.cooked:
Unless you're a Redux enthusiast, it's unlikely to find this helpful.

Most FRC CAN issues stem from wiring problems, whereas this adapter serves the purpose of capturing data frames rather than assessing electrical systems.

Reductionism aside, except for Redux which details their CAN message format on this link, FRC suppliers aren't inclined to share the database files necessary for deciphering CAN traffic off the wireâ€”using such an adapter would merely yield random bytes. Instead, tools like Phoenix Tuner or Hoot logs offer better functionality by decoding CAN traffic effectively.

Interestingly, before Redux, reverse-engineering CTRE CAN messages was relatively simple, though REV altered things, causing CTRE to become frustrated and subsequently hidudge the format. This has led automotive mentors to prefer direct CAN bus analysis. In my opinion, Vector CANalyzer remains superior for live sensor data monitoring, although access might be challenging.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC 548 Robostangs Electrical & Pneumatics Lead Mentor

posts.name: Ada T
posts.cooked: Are you sure? The 'old' Talon CAN protocols (that I used here, and that can be found in code on the CTRE github) are no longer in use. Recent Phoenix releases use different, obfuscated packet formats that I haven't yet succeeded in reverse engineering.
This Video covers what CAN should look like with an oscilloscope along with what it looks like during common problems.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked: Most of the CAN problems are due to wiring issues that can be identified using simpler tools and methods. Bad wiring might prevent the tool from detecting problems. Occasionally, Iâ€™ve encountered dead CAN ports. This device is particularly useful for developers creating devices that communicate over a CAN bus and verifying if their data protocols are implemented correctly.

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked:
These CAN debuggers are very useful for designing your own protocol but can be challenging when dealing with wiring issues. When wiring problems occur, you won't get any readings on the screen. Instead, you should test the resistance between your two CAN wires. A normal resistance should be around 60 Ohm. If it reads 120 Ohm, one termination resistor is missing. If it measures 0 Ohm, the wires are shorted, and if it's several kOhm, there's no termination on the line. Additionally, you can check the resistance between each line (power positive, power ground, and chassis) to identify any short circuits.

For users of FIRST Robotics Competition (FRC) systems, you don't need a separate debugger. If you have a REV CAN-connected device, the REV Hardware Client includes a built-in CAN Data function that allows you to view CAN frames directly.

I developed my own CAN implementation for FRC and had to design my own protocol on top of the FRC specification. My approach involved creating a custom protocol tailored to my specific needs.

Unless you want to create your own solutions or use a coprocessor, adapting an existing tool is limited. My preferred analyzer, the CANalyst-II, offers excellent performance but is hard to find in North America, and its software has poor English translations.

To address wiring issues:
1. Check the resistance between your CAN wires.
   - Normal: ~60 Ohm
   - High (120 Ohm): Missing termination resistor
   - Low (0 Ohm): Wires are shorted
   - Multiple kOhm: No termination present
2. Inspect the resistance between power positive, power ground, and chassis lines to locate any short circuits.

Using tools like the REV Hardware Client simplifies CAN communication verification, especially for FRC participants who may already have REV devices.

Custom CAN sensor - some good progress

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
Sometimes it is also necessary to check the resistance between each line to power positive, power ground and chassis and see if anything is shorter to those.

We spent about an hour trying to locate where a CAN wire was pressed against a sharp edge. The insulation was pierced, causing the CAN bus to become inoperative by shorting it to the chassis. Despite this, all open, short, and termination checks indicated everything was functioning properly. After extensive troubleshooting, we isolated the fault by bypassing sections of the CAN bus, narrowing it down to a specific run of wires, and subsequently replaced those wires.

posts.name: Chadfrom7226
posts.cooked:
If you really want to assess your CAN network quality, you can utilize tools like CANalyzer or CANoe. These tools provide insights into aspects such as bus utilization, collisions, and signal quality. However, they can be costly, so borrowing them might be necessary. 

On the other hand, maintaining a 60-ohm resistance across the CAN bus ensures optimal performance when all devices are connected. Any issues beyond that are typically related to configuration or programming settings.

posts.name: Chadfrom7226
posts.cooked: I just got one of those a few days ago. They seem to work pretty well with Python-CAN, although itâ€™s a somewhat unusual SL-CAN Controller Area Network protocol that you can utilize by converting it into a Socket CAN or connecting through a COM port in Windows.

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked: The best CAN analyzing tool a team have in hand is the one built in to REV. Even though it doesnâ€™t show utilization, it does show faults (error frames). If you want a stand-alone external analyzer, grab a REV device that you donâ€™t use and connect CAN to it. You donâ€™t need external power to use this CAN; data functions as USB will power the device. Only CAN and USB are needed to get it working. Additionally, itâ€™s smaller than a CANalyst. The best part of it is itâ€™s completely free (most teams should have access to an unused REV-connected device). Just plug in USB to a REV device, and it works. The downside is youâ€™re stuck with the REV hardware client compared to other analyzers.

posts.name: Nathan Zhou
posts.cooked:
https://canable.io/updater/

CANAble offers two types of firmware: SL-CAN and Candlelight. To switch modes, use the link above.

Candlelight firmware uses the USB protocol and works best with Python-Can if you have the right firmware on your adapter via the updater and the correct driver (libusb using zadig).

https://python-can.readthedocs.io/en/stable/interfaces/gs_usb.html#supported-platform

SL-CAN operates over Serial mode, offering better compatibility but being slower.

https://python-can.readthedocs.io/en/stable/interfaces/slcan.html

The form factor varies depending on the adapter, but all CANable units share the same software features.

Ensure your Python-Can setup correctly connects to the appropriate adapter in the right mode.

posts.cooked: Unless you decide to use a star topology. In that case, there could be a billion reasons for it not working.

posts.name: billbo911
posts.cooked: We use a combination of software and a CAN Controller Area Network map for diagnostics. When assembling the robot and finishing up the wiring, make sure to create an end-to-end map of each bus. By viewing the bus from each end, via Phoenix Configurator on the Rio, a PDH REVâ€™s Power Distribution Hub or SparkMax etc., you should be able to see all devices on the bus. If you only see a partial list, typically, the failure is just after the last one you see on the list. You can verify this by looking at the bus from the other end. And you should be able to see the remaining devices on the bus. Now that you know where the communication ends, you should be able to find where the error exists much more quickly.

posts.name: Ben Edwards
posts.cooked: An oscilloscope is highly recommended, though pricey, due to its extensive diagnostic capabilities. Look for equipment with clean edges and minimal ringing post-edge transitions. Both CANH and CANL channels should exhibit movement; CANH typically hovers around 3-4V, while CANL remains near 0V in dominant configurations. Recessive states show both lines near 2V. This setup helps identify potential faults such as shorts, improper terminations, or line Open conditions. Such insights extend diagnostics beyond mere Bus Off or Data Loss scenarios.

posts.name: Ezra
posts.cooked: Are there any that you would recommend or do you have any tips for finding one that fits our needs?

posts.name: Ben Edwards
posts.cooked:
The primary characteristics of any oscilloscope include bandwidth and the number of channels. Secondary features encompass sample rates (commonly found in modern digital scopes), user interfaces (such as knobs or screen sizes), trigger systems' complexities, measurement capabilities, protocol decoding, and accessory compatibility. Generally, users become aware of additional features through experience.

A good rule of thumb for mixed-signal diagnostics, like those involving CAN networks, is to ensure the oscilloscope's bandwidth is at least 10 times the signal clock rate. This setup allows observation of phenomena such as ringing and reflection without compromising accuracy.

For CAN FD applications, requiring at least 100MHz of bandwidth (10Mbit data rate) and two channels is essential.

Handheld scopes offer portability but often feature challenging user interfaces. For newcomers, a desktop "lunchbox" model with knobs and buttons is recommended due to its ease of use despite being tied to a wall outlet.

Gold-standard oscilloscopes from manufacturers like Tektronix, Teledyne-LeCroy, and Keysight command significant costs, largely determined by bandwidth and the number of channels. Basic 2-channel 100MHz scopes start around $2,000, with higher bandwidths priced at $4,000 and $12,000 respectively. Exorbitant models like a 4-channel 10GHz scope from Tektronix reach $170,000, with probes alone costing over $10,000.

Used scopes can be found inexpensively on platforms like Ebay or Facebook Marketplace, starting from approximately $200 for a 2-channel 100MHz unit, paired with affordable 100MHz probes ($30â€“$50). Used Tektronix scopes often prove more reliable and durable compared to new ones.

Portable scopes like the OWON HDS2102 are suitable for event-based CAN network diagnostics, albeit with a cumbersome interface. Desktop lunchboxes from Tek TDS are ideal for basic tasks, while high-bandwidth models from Teledyne-LeCroy cater to more demanding needs.

My preference lies in the portable OWON HDS2102 for its utility at events, combined with the dependable Tek TDS desktop units for everyday use, complemented by dedicated 1GHz LeCroy scopes for heavier tasks. My focus remains on embedded systems and motor control applications, necessitating less bandwidth-intensive setups.
